title: 108_hr898
content: The Act may be cited as the "Lumbee Recognition Act". The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to acknowledge the Lumbee Indians of North Carolina as descendants of coastal tribes, recognized by the State since 1885 and by Congress in 1956. The Lumbee Tribe, recognized by the State since 1885 and by Congress in 1956, should now receive full Federal recognition as an Indian tribe with all accompanying benefits and privileges. The Lumbee Tribe, recognized by the State since 1885 and by Congress in 1956, should now receive full Federal recognition as an Indian tribe with all accompanying benefits and privileges, including under SEC. 3. FEDERAL RECOGNITION. The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to extend Federal recognition to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, allowing them to receive all services and benefits provided to Indians. Indians in Robeson and adjoining counties not enrolled in the tribe may petition for tribal existence acknowledgment. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina is eligible for services and benefits as a federally recognized tribe. Members residing in specific counties are considered to be near an Indian reservation. The Secretary of the Interior and Health and Human Services will develop a budget for providing eligible services after verifying the tribal roll. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina is eligible for federal services and benefits as a recognized tribe. The Secretary of the Interior and Health and Human Services will submit a budget for these services based on the verified tribal roll. The tribal roll will define the service population, subject to verification by the Secretary of the Interior. Lands conveyed to the United States by the tribe will be treated as trust acquisitions. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina is eligible for federal services and benefits as a recognized tribe. The Secretary of the Interior will treat lands held in trust within Robeson County, North Carolina as 'on-reservation' trust acquisitions. The State of North Carolina will have jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on lands owned by the Lumbee Tribe. The Secretary of the Interior can accept transfers from the State of North Carolina on behalf of the United States. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina may transfer jurisdiction to the United States after consulting with the Attorney General. This transfer cannot take effect until 2 years after the agreement. The provisions in this subsection do not affect the Indian Child Welfare Act. Appropriations are authorized to carry out this Act.
